originContent: # DIY Smart Home Family Calendar (Skylight Clone)

originContent: My wife has been recently bombarded in social media with ads for smart home calendars (Skylight, Cozyla, Hearth) and was ready to spend over $300 on one. Before giving her the green light, I asked for a chance to research them.

√áoƒüu cihazƒ±n benzer i≈ülevsellik sunduƒüunu, ancak fiyatlarƒ±nƒ±n √∂nemli √∂l√ß√ºde farklƒ±lƒ±k g√∂sterdiƒüini fark ettim. En √∂nemlisi, **Home Assistant** ile uygulayamayacaƒüƒ±m olaƒüan√ºst√º bir √∂zellik de g√∂rmedim.

originContent: I realized most offered similar functionality but differed significantly in price. Most importantly, I didn't see any outstanding feature that I couldn't implement in **Home Assistant**.

originContent: **The Goal:** A WAF-approved (Wife Acceptance Factor), countertop-friendly touchscreen calendar that integrates deep into our smart home without monthly fees.

originContent: Choosing the DIY route with Home Assistant provided several benefits over buying a Skylight/Hearth display:
* **No Monthly Fees:** Avoids subscriptions for "premium" features.

originContent: * **Seamless Integration:** It talks to our lights, chores (Grocy), and presence sensors.

translatedContent: * **Gizlilik:** Satƒ±cƒ±ya baƒülƒ± kalma veya ≈üirketin kapanma riski yok.

originContent: * **Privacy:** No vendor lock-in or risk of the company shutting down.

originContent: In my case, the requirement was for it to "look like" skylight, be touchscreen, be countertop, possibility to move it to different locations. Therefore I went with the hardware described below.

originContent: The hardware I originally used I chose based on what I mentioned above plus with the hope to be able to extend functionality using the webcam, speaker and microphone. Currently I would probably build it differently now in hindsight, since I havent had time to address these additional hardware ideas.

originContent: * **Monitor:** [HP Engage 15-inch Touchscreen](https://computers.woot.com/offers/hp-engage-16t-fhd-monitor). I chose this over generic portable monitors because it includes a built-in **Speaker, Webcam, and Microphone**, allowing for future voice control or video calls.

translatedContent: `week-planner-card` belirli takvimleri anlƒ±k olarak gizlemeyi yerel olarak desteklemez. Bunu √ß√∂zmek i√ßin Regex filtresi gibi davranan **Girdi Metinleri** kullandƒ±m.

originContent: The `week-planner-card` does not natively support hiding specific calendars on the fly. To solve this, I used **Input Texts** acting as Regex filters.

translatedContent: * Bir ki≈üinin butonuna tƒ±kladƒ±ƒüƒ±nƒ±zda, filtresi `.*` (Her ≈üeyi g√∂ster) ile `^$` (Hi√ßbir ≈üey g√∂sterme) arasƒ±nda ge√ßi≈ü yapar.

originContent: * When you click a person's button, it toggles their filter between `.*` (Show everything) and `^$` (Show nothing).
translatedContent: * `config-template-card` bu deƒüi≈ükenleri takvim kartƒ±na dinamik olarak enjekte eder.

originContent: * `config-template-card` injects these variables into the calendar card dynamically.

originContent: The "Add Event" popup uses a single script that handles logic for multiple people and event types (All Day vs Timed).
My original post was just to give a high level overview of how to do it and allow people to adjust code to make it work in their specific scenarios.

originContent: In particular I did this because every display and need is different. I can't develop for all potential sizes of displays, dashboards, etc. So it is built to work in the display I mentioned or any (1920x1080) but should be editable for others.

originContent: Talking about display, I originally suggested that one because it was on sale at Woot and was a very economic way to get a touchscreen display at the time. This might not be the case now, so use whatever display works for you. Tablet, touchscreen, phone, whatever. The main thing youll need to edit is the dashboard.
